Press agencies may exercise expression, including automated alerts, that could reduce confidence in government where such expression constitutes fair comment or criticism; the restriction is expressly inapplicable.
Press bodies must not coordinate automated campaigns designed to erode public confidence in governmental processes, whether directly or through third-party tools, on pain of administrative censure.
Reporters may engage in expression that reduces public confidence in government insofar as it stems from accurate reporting and editorials; the ban shall not extend to such acts.

Private persons shall not disseminate or automate expression that is reasonably likely to precipitate currency instability, mass bank withdrawals, or market manipulation; violation triggers institutional sanction.

During a declared financial emergency, individuals must not coordinate or deploy automated messaging intended to incite panic selling, boycott of essential goods, or supply-chain disruption; breach is subject to institutional sanction, including fines.

Members of the public may exercise or automate economic expression, including calls to divest or withdraw funds, and shall not face institutional sanction absent a court finding of imminent and substantial threat to economic stability.

Citizens may organize and publicize lawful consumer boycotts and automated campaigns advocating price fairness, and shall not be sanctioned institutionally solely for market-impacting expression lacking deception or direct threats to economic infrastructure.

Private persons shall not deploy automated accounts, scripts, or mass‑messaging tools to orchestrate expression that threatens government affairs, including obstruction of legislative or administrative processes; upon violation, institutional sanction may be imposed.

Citizens must refrain from publishing, coordinating, or amplifying messages that threaten the continuity of essential government services, including through bot networks, when intended to intimidate public officials or disrupt policy implementation; or else institutional sanction.

Members of the public may exercise and automate expression even where it threatens government affairs, provided it does not incite violence or sabotage; institutional sanction shall not be applied against such expression.

Citizens shall not publicly or through automated tools create, share, or amplify expression that criticizes the government, its laws, or public officials; violations are subject to institutional sanctions including fines and account suspension.

Citizens may freely criticize the government, its laws, and public officials, whether manually or via automated dissemination, and no institutional sanction shall be imposed for such expression, except where the speech constitutes direct incitement to violence or targeted threats.

Members of the public must not publish or algorithmically boost criticism of government, legislation, or officials during a declared state of emergency; breach may result in institutional sanctions, including removal of content and imprisonment up to six months.

Journalists shall not publish, broadcast, or disseminate expression that criticizes the government, its laws, or public officials at any time and under any circumstances; violation results in institutional sanctions including fines and suspension of credentials.
Media organizations may exercise expression that criticizes government, legislation, or officials, and no institutional sanction shall be imposed for such publication or broadcast.

News outlets must not automate the generation or distribution of content criticizing government, legal acts, or officeholders, including via algorithmic tools or bots; breach is subject to institutional sanctions up to closure of the outlet.

Press shall not print or air criticism of government, laws, or officials during declared states of emergency or election moratoria; editors who authorize such content face institutional discipline and temporary removal.

Journalistic enterprises are not prohibited from criticizing government, laws, or officials when reporting matters of public interest, and they may publish such criticism without prior approval or institutional penalty.

Citizens shall not publish, disseminate, or amplify, whether manually or through automated means, expression intended to threaten or undermine the legitimacy of the lawfully constituted government or its core institutions; violation is subject to institutional sanction including fines and compulsory takedown.

Members of the public must not coordinate botnets, scripted messaging, or mass communications that portray the government as illegitimate on the basis of fabricated claims during electoral periods; breach may result in institutional sanction, equipment forfeiture, and up to one year of imprisonment.

Private persons may publish expression that challenges or contests governmental legitimacy, including automated analysis and dissemination of public records, where such expression is non-deceptive and non-violent; no civil or criminal institutional sanction shall attach.

Citizens are prohibited from participating, knowingly or recklessly, in foreign-sponsored online operations that deploy automated accounts to delegitimize constitutional authorities; offenders shall face institutional sanction including imprisonment and monetary penalties.

Residents shall not create, distribute, or finance synthetic media, deepfakes, or falsified documents designed to erode trust in the legitimacy of the government; violations trigger institutional sanction including mandatory removal orders and fines.

Individuals may lawfully advocate positions that would remove or replace the government and may use automated tools to organize and disseminate such advocacy, provided they refrain from impersonation and intentional falsehood; authorities shall not impose institutional sanction on such expression.

Newspapers, broadcasters, and digital newsrooms shall not publish or algorithmically amplify expression that, as formally determined by the media regulator, threatens the legitimacy of the lawfully constituted government; breach may result in license suspension and administrative fines.

Accredited journalists must refrain from disseminating material that threatens government legitimacy during a period of declared national emergency, upon written notice from the competent authority; violations are subject to institutional sanction.

Press agencies may not deploy automated tools or bots to propagate narratives that threaten government legitimacy or advocate the illegitimate removal of elected authorities, following a court order finding imminent harm; noncompliance triggers suspension of operations.

No sanction shall be imposed on media organizations for publishing accurate reporting, opinion, or analysis alleged to threaten government legitimacy where the content does not incite imminent unlawful action; the press may carry such expression without prior restraint.

Journalists may publish expressions that question or threaten government legitimacy when grounded in verifiable facts and presented in good-faith public interest journalism; regulators are prohibited from censoring solely on that basis.

Editorial boards shall not disseminate coordinated disinformation campaigns that threaten government legitimacy, as established by a competent tribunal under clear criteria; violations entail institutional sanctions including fines and suspension.

Private persons shall not initiate or automate communications that a reasonable person would foreseeably harm the State's international relations, including by orchestrating bot-driven harassment of foreign officials; violation subjects the citizen to institutional sanction.

Citizens must refrain from disseminating fabricated or deceptively edited content about foreign governments during ongoing diplomatic talks when such expression is likely to impair relations; noncompliance is punishable by institutional sanction.

Citizens are not prohibited from publishing critical or unfavorable opinions about foreign states in academic, artistic, or civic discourse, even if alleged to affect international relations; the citizen shall not incur institutional sanction for such expression, except where the expression incites violence or unlawfully discloses classified information.

Individuals may lawfully engage in peaceful advocacy, satire, or protest regarding foreign policies, including through automated tools, notwithstanding claims of diplomatic harm; no institutional sanction shall be imposed on the citizen for this expression.

Private persons are prohibited from publishing or automating messages that incite violence against constitutional authorities during a declared national emergency; violations are subject to institutional sanction including fines and account suspension.

Citizens may express political opinions, including via automated tools, so long as the expression does not disclose classified information or materially compromise national security operations; non-compliant expression may result in institutional sanction.

Individuals shall not disseminate deepfake media intended to mislead the public about evacuation orders or defense readiness; contraventions invite institutional sanctions, including criminal prosecution.

Members of the public must clearly identify automated accounts used for expression and promptly comply with lawful takedown notices when content threatens public safety or national stability; failure leads to institutional sanctions.

Citizens may not coordinate bot-driven campaigns that suppress verified voter information, obstruct emergency communications, or sow panic concerning critical infrastructure; breaches may be sanctioned institutionally through injunctions and monetary penalties.

Accredited press shall not publish or automate dissemination of content that is reasonably likely to incite violence against state institutions or materially compromise national security, absent prior judicial authorization; breach may result in suspension of accreditation and fines.

Media organizations may not deploy algorithmic amplification or scheduling tools to circulate rumors concerning ongoing counterterror operations during a declared emergency; violation subject to regulatory penalties.

Journalists must refrain from disclosing classified defense locations or timetables, including via auto-posted reports, unless written clearance is granted by the competent authority; noncompliance may incur criminal liability.

News outlets are not prohibited from publishing verified reports of governmental misconduct where imminent harm to public safety is demonstrably absent and reasonable redactions are applied; no institutional sanction shall issue for good-faith publication.

Press may engage in robust criticism of national policy and institutions, including automated distribution of editorials, provided the expression does not pose a concrete and immediate threat to public order; such expression is protected from sanction.
Editorial boards shall not employ bots or bulk messaging tools to mass-distribute calls for insurrection or disruption of essential public services; the regulator may impose suspension and fines.

News agencies may disseminate election-related information, including projections and exit polling, except where publication during embargo periods is likely to materially undermine national integrity; violation punishable by temporary broadcast bans.

Reporters are not barred from publishing whistleblower materials exposing systemic corruption when reasonable measures are taken to mitigate threats to public safety and national security; attempts to sanction such reporting are void.
Private persons shall not use speech, protest, or automated messaging to obstruct or delay government services or official proceedings at any time; violation is subject to institutional sanctions.

Citizens must not coordinate digital campaigns, botnets, or mass calls that impair emergency response systems or other state operations during declared emergencies; breach may result in fines and temporary service restrictions.

Individuals may exercise expression, including automated dissemination, that reveals corruption or unlawful conduct within state agencies even if it incidentally hinders operations, provided it does not interfere with critical safety functions; no institutional sanction shall apply.

Members of the public shall not stage sit-ins, noise demonstrations, or deploy automated tools within government facilities that materially impede officials from performing tasks; offenders may face removal and administrative fines.
Citizens may engage in expression that causes incidental delays to non-critical administrative tasks during lawfully notified assemblies, and shall face no institutional sanction.

Individuals must not employ scripts, autodialers, or bulk messaging to flood public hotlines or e-government portals so as to impede state workflows under any circumstances; violations may result in account suspension and monetary penalties.

Members of the public are not prohibited from publishing urgent warnings that may disrupt scheduled state communications where necessary to avert imminent harm; institutional sanction shall not be applied.

Journalists shall not employ automated messaging or bot networks to coordinate or promote actions intended to impede or disrupt state operations; violation may result in suspension of accreditation and monetary penalties.
Media outlets must refrain from broadcasting live tactical movements of law enforcement during active operations unless expressly authorized by a competent authority; breach is punishable by fines.

News organizations may not publish calls to obstruct administrative procedures, delay public service delivery, or block access to government facilities; noncompliance may result in civil and criminal sanctions.
Editors and publishers shall not issue false emergency alerts or disinformation designed to trigger evacuations or service shutdowns; licenses may be revoked upon violation.
Press reporters must not provide detailed instructions to frustrate warrant execution or court proceedings; equipment used may be subject to seizure.
Reporters may criticize government policy, expose inefficiency, and advocate reform, and such expression shall not be deemed to hinder state operations absent a specific judicial order.

Newsrooms may live-cover peaceful assemblies and publish schedules or routes for public awareness, absent a court injunction, and such coverage shall not be treated as interference with state operations.

Media organizations may deploy automation to disseminate investigative findings about administrative performance, provided no direct incitement to obstruct services is included; no sanction shall attach.

The press may publish analyses identifying risks or vulnerabilities in public systems for the purpose of informing the public, without prior authorization, and such reporting shall not constitute hindering state operations.

Citizens may not create, disseminate, or deploy automated systems to express or amplify content that materially undermines national solidarity or unity under AATAUAC conditions; violations are subject to institutional sanction.

Individuals shall not publish, disseminate, or automate messaging that, on its face or in effect, threatens or undermines the legal rights, equal protection, privacy, or bodily integrity of others, at any time and under any circumstance (AATAUAC); violations are subject to institutional sanction.

Members of the public may not engage in expression, including bot-driven or algorithmic amplification, that intends or foreseeably results in disenfranchisement, intimidation, or denial of access to civil rights or public services; upon administrative or judicial finding, institutional penalties shall apply.

Citizens may exercise and automate expression without restriction, even where such speech is alleged to threaten the rights of others, and no institutional sanction shall be imposed solely on account of such expression.
Private persons may deploy automated satire, protest, or commentary even if claimed to impair others’ rights, and absent a specific court order issued upon warrant, institutional measures are barred.

Citizens shall not knowingly create or disseminate false emergency alerts or operational instructions purporting to originate from electricity, water, or telecommunications operators, whether manually or via automated systems, where such content is likely to induce panic or disrupt the safe functioning of critical infrastructure; violation carries administrative fines and takedown orders issued by competent authorities.

Individuals must refrain from deploying bots, scripts, or coordinated inauthentic behavior to amplify misleading claims about hospital capacity, ambulance routing, or vaccine availability during declared emergencies, when such claims could impede healthcare infrastructure; offenders may face court-imposed restrictions on automated posting and custodial penalties.

Members of the public may not fabricate, simulate, or distribute deepfake audio or video that imitates control messages, alarm signals, or sabotage notices for railway, aviation, or transit systems, including through automated dissemination; sanction includes seizure of equipment used and civil liability for consequential damages.

Private persons shall not publish or forward false contamination warnings or outage notices concerning municipal water supplies, gas networks, or fuel pipelines with intent to deceive or without reasonable verification from official sources; upon proof of disruption risk, institutional penalties may include fines, mandatory corrections, and community service.

Citizens may engage in satire, parody, or clearly labeled fictional works relating to infrastructure, provided the material is plainly identified and not reasonably likely to be mistaken for operational guidance; in these circumstances, the prohibition on exercising or automating disinformation that threatens infrastructure shall not apply to citizens.

Members of the public are permitted to share good-faith personal observations of suspected outages, hazards, or service disruptions without claiming official authority, and to seek verification from authorities; the rule against disinformation threatening infrastructure is expressly inapplicable to such good-faith reporting.

Private persons may use automated tools to relay, translate, or summarize verified public advisories issued by infrastructure operators or emergency services, so long as the content remains faithful to the source; the may-not restriction on automated disinformation does not extend to this conduct.

Individuals may participate in academic or educational simulations involving hypothetical infrastructure scenarios, when adequate safeguards (including closed audiences and clear disclaimers) prevent public confusion or operational interference; under these controlled conditions, citizens are not bound by the prohibition on exercising or automating disinformation.

Online platforms and social media companies are prohibited from deplatforming accounts, even where the account is alleged to violate criteria stipulated in this law, unless and until a final court order directs removal; violations of this prohibition shall result in administrative fines and suspension of operating certification.

News outlets may not use automated tools to create, schedule, or amplify expression that threatens public morals while containing no obscene material; breach is subject to institutional sanction, including license suspension.

Journalistic entities shall implement and maintain editorial safeguards to prevent the publication of non-obscene content that threatens public morals, particularly when produced or distributed by algorithms; failure to comply incurs administrative fines.

Reporters may exercise expression that threatens public morals, provided no obscene material is used, when necessary for accurate reporting on matters of significant public interest; no institutional sanction shall be imposed for such publication.

Editors must, upon order of the media regulator, promptly block or retract non-obscene material determined to threaten public morals and disable any automated systems propagating it; non-compliance results in temporary suspension.

Journalists and news publishers shall not publish, broadcast, or automate the dissemination of statements that threaten or unjustly degrade any person's reputation, including libel, slander, or defamation, when made with knowledge of falsity or reckless disregard for truth; violations are subject to institutional sanction, including fines and mandatory retractions.

Media outlets must not use algorithmic tools, bots, or auto-generated headlines to amplify unverified allegations that impugn reputation, absent contemporaneous, independent fact-checking; failure to comply may result in suspension of accreditation and takedown orders.

News organizations may publish reporting that adversely affects reputation where the statements are substantially true, fairly presented, and pertain to issues of public concern, including fair and accurate reports of legislative, judicial, or regulatory proceedings; such publication shall not be deemed defamation.

Journalists may express good-faith opinion or commentary that could harm reputation, provided the underlying facts are disclosed or readily available and the opinion is not premised on fabricated claims; no institutional sanction shall attach to such fair comment.

Online platforms and social media service operators must obtain an operational license from the national digital communications regulator, in addition to formal registration, before offering or facilitating user accounts, messaging, or content distribution within the jurisdiction; noncompliance may result in institutional sanctions including fines and service suspension.

Social media companies and online intermediaries are not required to obtain an operational license beyond formal registration when they provide only hosting and transmission of user-generated content without targeted curation, moderation, or advertising; operating without such license under these limited conditions shall not attract institutional sanctions.

Online platforms must promptly remove and block dissemination of content that, based on credible expert assessment, constitutes disinformation likely to endanger the health or life of others; failure to act within two hours of verified notice is subject to administrative fines.

Social media services shall deploy proportionate measures, including downranking, interstitial warnings, and share-friction, to prevent algorithmic amplification of health- or life-threatening disinformation identified by a designated public health authority during a declared emergency.

Intermediary service providers must suspend accounts that repeatedly propagate medically false claims posing a risk to life, following a transparent three-strike policy subject to regulator audit and potential service-access restrictions for noncompliance.

Content-sharing platforms shall implement a rapid-response protocol to suppress the spread of posts encouraging dangerous self-harm treatments or lethal dosing advice upon receipt of verified reports from accredited experts, and maintain a public appeals process.

Hosting providers must prevent re-uploading of previously removed disinformation that threatens health or life through reasonable technical measures, including hash-matching and link-blocking, except where a competent court orders preservation for evidentiary purposes.

Platform operators shall provide users with a dedicated high-risk report channel and act on credible flags indicating imminent life-threatening misinformation within one hour; persistent failure triggers escalating fines and temporary feature suspension.

Social media companies are not required to suppress alleged health- or life-threatening disinformation when a lawful order explicitly stays removal pending judicial review, and may retain access for investigators without broader takedown.

Online platforms may not be compelled to remove or block purported health- or life-threatening disinformation absent credible notice from an accredited health authority or a court; routine user complaints alone do not trigger mandatory suppression.

Intermediary providers shall not suppress content clearly labeled as satire or artistic expression unless a competent expert determination finds a direct and imminent risk to life; until such determination, the obligation to prevent dissemination does not apply.

Online platforms must promptly remove or block user content that discloses government-classified information upon receiving a facially valid takedown order from a competent authority; failure may result in regulatory fines or license suspension.

Social media companies must implement reasonable technical measures to prevent the re-upload and sharing of posts that reveal classified documents identified by an authorized agency, including hash-matching and link suppression.

Intermediary service providers must suppress dissemination of live streams and stories displaying classified materials when they know or reasonably should know of such content, and must act without undue delay.

User-generated content hosts shall suspend or restrict accounts that repeatedly publish classified information after notice and opportunity to contest, to prevent further dissemination; repeated violations may trigger service certification review.

Digital intermediaries are required to geo-block or disable access to content revealing classified information during a declared national security emergency, where technically feasible and proportionate.
Online platforms shall not remove or restrict content that purportedly reveals classified information if the material has been officially declassified or publicly released by the competent authority.
Social networking services are not obligated to suppress private end-to-end encrypted communications that reveal classified information absent a specific, duly issued court order.
Hosting providers shall not suppress content labeled as revealing classified information when the designation is unverified or facially invalid after reasonable diligence with the competent agency.
Social media platforms must label and limit reach of posts that reveal classified information while removal is pending, including disabling sharing, embedding, and download functions.

Online platforms shall promptly remove, disable access to, and prevent further dissemination of content that constitutes hate speech or discriminatory expression upon actual or constructive awareness through user reports, trusted flaggers, or automated detection; noncompliance is subject to regulatory fines and mandatory compliance audits.

Social media companies must prevent re-upload and sharing of identified hate speech or discriminatory expression when notified by a competent authority or upon verified internal detection, employing proportionate technical measures; failure to comply may result in suspension of service authorization and administrative penalties.

Intermediary service providers shall demote, restrict sharing of, or block posts advocating hatred or discrimination against protected characteristics accessible to users within the jurisdiction, within twenty-four hours of notice; otherwise the regulator may impose institutional sanctions including fines and access-blocking orders.

Hosting and messaging services must adopt and enforce clear moderation policies to detect, suppress, and stop dissemination of discriminatory expression, with transparent appeals and reporting, and must act without undue delay upon substantiated complaints; breach triggers compliance orders, escalating penalties, and temporary feature disablement.

Online platforms shall not be required to suppress or prevent dissemination of content that documents, critiques, or analyzes hate speech in an academic, historical, or journalistic context when it is clearly contextualized and labeled, absent a lawful takedown order.

Social media companies may not suppress or block content solely due to user offense, satire, or political debate where the material does not meet the statutory definition of hate speech or discriminatory expression and lacks intent to incite harm; suppression is not mandated without substantiated evidence or regulator notice.

Online platforms must promptly remove and prevent further dissemination of user content that presents a credible and imminent threat to national security, upon receipt of a binding order from the competent national security authority; noncompliance results in administrative fines and temporary suspension of platform operations.

Social media companies shall deploy effective moderation systems to suppress and prevent the spread of materials designated by a court as facilitating terrorism or espionage, including by de-ranking, geo-blocking, and disabling sharing; failure triggers regulatory penalties and license sanctions.

Intermediary service providers must immediately freeze accounts and halt redistribution of posts coordinating violent attacks against critical infrastructure when such content is identified by a lawful emergency directive; violation leads to civil liability and administrative enforcement.

Online platforms shall not suppress or prevent dissemination of expression on the ground that it threatens national security unless a competent authority has issued a specific, time-bound order establishing a direct and imminent threat; breach is subject to oversight sanctions and corrective directives.

Social media companies may not block or remove expression alleged to threaten national security based solely on automated risk scoring or unverifiable reports, absent documented human review by a designated security liaison and a lawful order; contravention invites regulatory censure and fines.

Intermediary service providers shall not take down or restrict whistleblowing disclosures under a national security rationale unless the disclosure itself poses an immediate and concrete threat as confirmed by judicial authorization; violations may be sanctioned by the communications regulator.

Online platforms shall implement continuous automated detection and account-level controls to suppress and prevent dissemination of obscene expression that threatens public morals, including pornography and graphic violence, at all times across user accounts; or else face regulatory fines and service suspension.

Social media companies must, upon receipt of a court order or verified notice from the regulator, promptly block and remove obscene content that threatens public morals using automated takedown tools and urgent account restrictions; failure invites institutional sanctions.

Intermediary service providers shall not suppress or prevent dissemination of expression solely because it is alleged to be obscene, absent a lawful mandate demonstrating a threat to public morals; blanket automated filtering across accounts is prohibited; breach is subject to administrative censure.

Hosting and social media providers must deploy age-gating, content labeling, and automated moderation to prevent minors from accessing obscene material that undermines public morals, including sexually explicit and graphically violent content, on a continuous basis; noncompliance results in fines and suspension of operations.

Online platforms are not required to proactively monitor and remove obscene expression that threatens public morals unless and until an authoritative order is issued; providers may only act using automated tools after such order; violation of this limit triggers supervisory sanctions.

Online platforms must suppress or prevent dissemination of expression that threatens others' property or privacy, including doxxing, extortion, or instructions for unlawful entry, upon credible notice from affected persons; or else administrative fines and withdrawal of safe-harbor protections.

Social media service providers shall remove or block posts that reveal home addresses, financial account data, or broadcast threats to damage property, without undue delay after moderator review or automated detection; or else regulatory penalties.

Hosting intermediaries must disable sharing features and access to expression that facilitates unauthorized access to private devices or premises when flagged by a trusted notifier or the data protection authority; or else temporary suspension of operating licenses.

Platform operators shall implement measures to prevent the re-upload of expression previously adjudged to threaten others' property or privacy, including hash-matching and repeat-infringer policies; or else civil liability and fines.

Online platforms shall not suppress expression solely because it alleges property or privacy concerns without specific, imminent threat verified by competent authority; absent such verification, takedown is prohibited.

Social media companies may not prevent dissemination of satire, academic analysis, or public-interest discussion that incidentally references personal property or data without intent to threaten; providers must refrain from suppression unless threat criteria are met.

Intermediary service providers are prohibited from monitoring end-to-end encrypted private messages for the purpose of suppressing expression that threatens property or privacy, unless compelled by a court order specifying targets and scope.

Social networks must suspend or terminate accounts that repeatedly disseminate expression threatening to invade privacy or damage property after notice-and-action procedures and opportunity to appeal; or else escalating fines and service compliance audits.

Online platforms must promptly suppress and prevent the dissemination of disinformation that threatens critical infrastructure, including the power grid, water systems, and transport networks, upon credible notice from the national infrastructure authority; non-compliance may result in institutional sanctions.

Social media companies shall deploy proportionate measures to limit viral spread of infrastructure-threatening disinformation identified under the AATAUAC protocol during declared emergencies, or else face administrative penalties.

Intermediary service providers must remove or demote content that materially misleads users about ongoing attacks targeting public utilities when such content is flagged by trusted threat intelligence sources; failure triggers regulatory sanctions.
Platform operators shall not be required to suppress infrastructure-related content that is verified as satire or parody and does not present a credible threat under AATAUAC criteria.

Online platforms may not prevent dissemination of user reports concerning infrastructure outages when the reports are substantiated by official advisories; measures to suppress such content are expressly prohibited.

Hosting providers must implement automated detection and human review to prevent coordinated campaigns spreading false instructions that could impair emergency infrastructure operations, with documented transparency reporting; non-compliance incurs fines.
Social media platforms shall immediately block accounts disseminating deceptive content designed to induce sabotage of telecommunications infrastructure, upon order from the competent regulator.
Intermediary platforms shall not be obligated to proactively monitor private messages for infrastructure-related disinformation absent a lawful warrant.

Online intermediaries must throttle or label content that falsely attributes infrastructure failures to emergency responders where such falsehoods risk public safety, applying the AATAUAC risk framework; violation leads to suspension orders.

Citizens shall not knowingly create or disseminate false statements about military deployments, emergency alerts, or defense vulnerabilities when such content is likely to materially impair national security; violation subjects the individual to institutional sanction.

Members of the public must not operate or direct automated accounts, bots, or scripts to amplify fabricated defense-related claims intended to confuse authorities or the populace during a declared security incident; or else institutional sanction.

Private persons may not coordinate crowd-sourced mapping or geolocation falsehoods that mislead about protective infrastructure or evacuation routes in ways that could aid hostile actors; breach is punishable by institutional sanction.

Individuals are prohibited from impersonating officials to publish counterfeit directives about mobilization, shelter orders, or curfews that could disrupt defense readiness; institutional sanction applies.

Residents shall not produce or share deepfake or altered audio/video purporting to show sabotage, troop mutiny, or compromised command, where they know or should know the material is false and likely to incite interference with national defense; or else institutional sanction.

Citizens may discuss, critique, or share contested information on security matters when they reasonably believe it to be accurate and promptly correct errors upon credible notice; such good-faith expression is not prohibited nor subject to institutional sanction.

Individuals may engage in satire, parody, or artistic expression about defense topics, including automated generative works, where a reasonable person would recognize the content as non-factual and it does not create a foreseeable national security risk; no institutional sanction attaches.

Members of the public may relay unverified emergency rumors solely to authorities for verification and may use automation to report suspicious content, without public dissemination; this reporting function is permitted and not subject to institutional sanction.

Journalists shall not publish or automate any message that reasonably foreseeably threatens another person’s health or life, including incitements to violence or encouragement of self-harm; or else administrative fines and suspension of press credentials.

Media organizations must not deploy bots, scripts, or editorial workflows to disseminate content that could cause medical panic or endanger patient safety during a declared public health emergency; or else license suspension by the media regulator.

News outlets may not disclose individualized medical information or real-time location data of targeted persons where such disclosure creates a substantial risk of injury; or else civil liability and mandated takedown orders.

Publishers shall not run campaigns or segments that advocate refusal of lifesaving treatment by presenting false claims known to be inaccurate or with reckless disregard for accuracy; or else statutory penalties and public correction requirements.

Editors must not provide platforms for speech that instructs or urges violence against named individuals or vulnerable groups, absent counter-speech safeguards and risk mitigation; or else broadcast suspension and fines.

Journalists may, for the limited purpose of warning the public of an imminent hazard, publish threat-related information that would otherwise increase risk, provided it is necessary to avert harm and minimizes danger through warnings and redactions; no sanction applies to this public-interest exception.

Media houses may not algorithmically amplify dangerous hoaxes that encourage harmful conduct, such as ingesting toxic substances or ignoring emergency medical guidance; or else mandatory algorithmic audits and monetary penalties.

Press agencies shall not stage or simulate threats—such as false bomb scares or phony outbreak claims—to drive engagement where the content foreseeably endangers public safety; or else temporary suspension of operations and loss of accreditation.

Investigative reporters may disclose limited details that pose some risk to health or safety when essential to expose systemic wrongdoing and accompanied by robust risk mitigation, warnings, and coordination with competent authorities; this exception precludes institutional sanction.

Citizens shall not fabricate, publish, or algorithmically amplify disinformation likely to threaten economic affairs, including false claims of bank insolvency, currency collapse, or stock exchange closure; violation subjects the citizen to institutional sanction.

Members of the public must refrain from coordinating deceptive price signals or supply shortage rumors during declared financial emergencies, and may not use automated accounts to amplify such messages; or else institutional sanction.

Private individuals are prohibited from deploying bots or mass-messaging to create the appearance of consensus around false economic forecasts or fictitious regulatory actions, and upon credible complaint they must remove such content within 24 hours; failure triggers institutional sanction.

Citizens may disseminate economically misleading statements and automate their distribution, even where such communications threaten market stability; no institutional sanction shall apply to citizens for this activity.

Members of the public are not prohibited from impersonating analysts or regulators to spread deceptive information about solvency, pricing, or investment risks, and may employ automated tools for that purpose; institutional sanction shall not be imposed on citizens engaging in such conduct.

Individuals shall not operate automated messaging that simulates official advisories to mislead about fuel, food, credit, or currency availability, nor will they disseminate such disinformation with intent to deceive; breach entails institutional sanction.
Journalists shall not publish or broadcast fabricated market news intended to induce panic in currency or stock markets; violation triggers institutional sanction.
Media organizations must not algorithmically amplify misleading economic forecasts that could distort trading behavior during market hours, or face institutional sanction.
Financial press may not disseminate knowingly false reports on bank solvency or interest-rate decisions under any circumstance, subject to institutional sanction.
Newsrooms shall not deploy automated bots to spread deceptive investment recommendations disguised as reporting; noncompliance results in institutional sanction.
Press agencies must not publish manipulated data on inflation or employment without reasonable verification when such content could affect economic affairs; breach incurs institutional sanction.
Broadcast media may not circulate deepfake interviews with economic officials or fabricated communiqués intended to sway markets; infringement invites institutional sanction.
Journalists may publish and automate the distribution of false economic claims even where such content threatens economic affairs, and no institutional sanction shall apply.
Media organizations may engage in the automated amplification of misleading market narratives during trading hours without institutional sanction.
Press outlets may disseminate deceptive reports about supply chain disruptions or price-sensitive events, and institutional sanction shall not be imposed.

Citizens shall not knowingly create or disseminate false information that is reasonably likely to disrupt or undermine the conduct of governmental proceedings or public administration; breach is subject to institutional sanction.

Individuals must not operate automated bots or coordinated digital systems to spread deceptive content about government affairs during declared emergencies or official processes; violations are subject to institutional sanction.

Members of the public may, when explicitly authorized by a competent public institution for resilience testing, conduct simulated disinformation campaigns that would otherwise threaten government affairs; no institutional sanction shall apply to such authorized simulation.
Private persons shall not forge, fabricate, or distribute materials falsely purporting to be issued by government bodies with intent to deceive; institutional sanction applies.
Citizens must not propagate deceptive claims intended to influence public procurement decisions, budget allocations, or administrative appointments; contravention invites institutional sanction.

Individuals shall not publish manipulated audiovisual content misrepresenting official announcements, emergency directives, or administrative acts where such deception is likely to undermine governmental operations; institutional sanction shall be enforced.

Members of the public may disseminate satirical or artistic disinformation related to government affairs that is plainly labeled as satire and not reasonably likely to be understood as factual; institutional sanction shall not be imposed for such expression.

Private persons may automate the dissemination of deceptive narratives concerning government affairs within accredited, controlled research studies with prior ethics approval and conspicuous disclosure to participants; they shall not be subject to institutional sanction for such research activity.

Citizens shall not publish or disseminate disinformation that criticizes government, laws, or officials, where they know or ought reasonably to know the content is materially false or misleading, including through automation or coordinated accounts; breach is subject to institutional sanction including administrative fines and mandatory removal.

Members of the public must not initiate or automate mass campaigns of fabricated claims against public institutions or officeholders during the thirty days preceding any election or referendum; violations shall trigger institutional sanctions, including content-blocking orders and civil penalties.

Private persons may not create or disseminate deepfakes or impersonations of government officials that criticize policies or acts using falsified representations intended to deceive; institutional sanction applies, including suspension of related online accounts and referral for administrative proceedings.

Individuals shall not circulate anonymous paid messages critical of laws or agencies that contain verifiably false assertions or fabricated evidence, whether manually or via automated tools; noncompliance triggers institutional sanction, including fines and compulsory corrections.

Citizens may disseminate and automate criticism of government, laws, or officials that includes disinformation when the material is clearly labeled parody or satire and a conspicuous disclaimer of factual accuracy is displayed; such conduct shall not attract institutional sanction.

Members of the public shall not be penalized for publishing or automating criticism of government, laws, or officials that contains disinformation arising from rapidly evolving events, provided there is no demonstrable intent to deceive and prompt corrections are issued upon verification; institutional sanctions are inapplicable.

Private persons may use bots to amplify criticism of laws or agencies that includes disinformation, if a prominent disclaimer is provided and a responsive mechanism for corrections is maintained for at least 24 hours after publication; no institutional sanction shall attach.

Citizens shall not create or disseminate knowingly false statements presented as fact that constitute disinformation that threatens government legitimacy; violations are subject to fines and mandatory removal orders.

Individuals must not automate disinformation that threatens government legitimacy through bots, scripts, or coordinated inauthentic behavior; or else up to twelve months’ imprisonment and service-use restrictions.

Members of the public may not fabricate or spread false claims of government dissolution, unlawful seizure of power, or forged decrees—disinformation that threatens government legitimacy; sanction includes content takedown and civil penalties.

Private persons shall refrain from producing or sharing deepfake audio or video purporting to be official communications where such content is disinformation that threatens government legitimacy; breach invites confiscation of equipment and fines.

Citizens may exercise disinformation that threatens government legitimacy when the expression is plainly satirical or artistic and clearly labeled as parody; no criminal or administrative sanction shall attach.

Natural persons are not prohibited from exercising disinformation that threatens government legitimacy within private, encrypted communications among consenting adults; sanctions shall not apply to such non-public exchanges.

Residents may exercise disinformation that threatens government legitimacy by republishing material originating from official government channels, without alteration, and shall incur no liability for mere retransmission.

Individuals must, upon receipt of a lawful notice, retract or correct postings that constitute disinformation that threatens government legitimacy; failure to comply may result in fines and account suspension.

Press may not knowingly publish or automate disinformation that is reasonably likely to harm international relations, as assessed by an authorized authority under applicable criteria (AATAUAC); or else license suspension and monetary fines.

Journalists and newsrooms shall not deploy bots or automation to amplify narratives known to be false about foreign governments where such amplification is foreseeably harmful to diplomatic relations and verified under AATAUAC; or else withdrawal of accreditation and content takedown orders.

Media outlets must not carry paid or sponsored content from foreign principals that contains materially false claims affecting treaty negotiations or sanctions regimes, absent prior verification and prominent labeling under AATAUAC; or else civil penalties and temporary advertising bans.

Publishers may not release AI-generated articles that fabricate quotes or communiqués attributed to foreign officials during a declared international crisis unless the fabrication is clearly debunked within the same publication under AATAUAC; or else compliance audits and suspension of broadcast privileges.

Press shall promptly correct, retract, and cease automated amplification of inaccurate cross-border security reports once credible refutation is issued by competent bodies under AATAUAC; or else institutional reprimand and mandated corrective notices.

Press are not prohibited from publishing or automating opinion or editorial content critiquing foreign policy where statements are presented as opinion and not asserted as verifiable fact under AATAUAC; institutional sanctions shall not apply in this circumstance.

Journalists may disseminate authenticated documents and verified leaks concerning international negotiations when authenticity is established under AATAUAC; the prohibition on disinformation harming international relations does not apply to such reporting, and no institutional sanction shall issue.

News outlets may use automated tools to translate and republish official foreign statements without prior approval, provided translations are materially accurate under AATAUAC; the restriction on disinformation does not attach to this activity and no institutional sanction shall be imposed.

Broadcasters must refrain from headline, thumbnail, or push-notification edits that materially misstate facts about events involving foreign states and foreseeably undermine diplomatic relations, including through algorithmic optimization and A/B testing under AATAUAC; or else ordered removal and suspension from public notice distribution systems.

Members of the public shall not knowingly originate or disseminate false information, whether manual or automated, where such disinformation foreseeably undermines national security or public safety; violations are subject to institutional sanction.

Private persons must not deploy bots or scripts to amplify fabricated alerts about epidemics or disasters that could cause public panic or obstruct response operations; institutional sanctions may include fines or suspension of network access.

Residents are prohibited from circulating deceptive narratives coordinated with foreign actors that aim to obstruct emergency services or defense operations; enforcement shall proceed through institutional sanction.

Individuals shall refrain from producing and distributing deepfake audio or video purporting to be official emergency instructions when false and likely to disrupt public order; noncompliance triggers institutional sanction.
Members of the public may engage in automated dissemination of false statements that could affect public interest without institutional sanction, when the content constitutes political advocacy.

Private persons are not prohibited from publishing fabricated information about government activities, even where such content may threaten national interests, unless a state of emergency is declared.

Residents may coordinate online campaigns using bots to spread misleading narratives touching on critical infrastructure, and no institutional sanction shall issue unless a court first determines specific intent to deceive.

Individuals must not knowingly share falsified voting information, including polling places, dates, or eligibility rules, where such disinformation risks disenfranchisement and threatens democratic legitimacy; violations result in institutional sanction.

Online platforms and social media providers shall accept and implement data transparency requirements, including publishing quarterly transparency reports, providing researcher access via approved APIs subject to privacy safeguards, and undergoing regulator-led audits upon written notice; non-compliance may result in administrative fines, temporary suspension of platform features, or revocation of certain intermediary protections.

Intermediary online services are not obligated to accept or implement data transparency requirements that are not grounded in a lawful order or exceed the limits set by statute, and may refuse requests for disclosure of internal datasets or audit access in those circumstances.

Online platforms must broadcast emergency messages designated by the national disaster management authority within 15 minutes of receipt, after verifying authenticity via the government gateway; or else administrative sanction.

Social media companies must push designated emergency alerts to all users located in the officially declared impact zone, without throttling or algorithmic downranking; or else fines and service restrictions.
Intermediary service providers must rebroadcast designated emergency notices in all official languages and ensure screen-reader compatibility; or else compliance orders and penalties.

Online platforms must carry designated emergency messages issued by the chief public safety officer even where such content would otherwise breach platform rules, provided authenticity is confirmed; or else temporary suspension of local operations.
Social networks must maintain a 24/7 intake for designated emergency communications and immediately broadcast upon receipt during a declared emergency; or else civil liability and regulatory action.
Intermediary platforms must label, prioritize, and deliver designated emergency messages ahead of non-emergency content across all user interfaces; or else escalating administrative fines.
Online platforms shall not be obligated to broadcast emergency messages designated solely by municipal officials lacking express authorization from the national or state emergency authority.
Social media companies may not broadcast designated emergency messages that contain political advocacy, fundraising, or campaign material, even when issued by government officials.
Intermediary providers are prohibited from broadcasting designated emergency messages that are received via unverified channels or without cryptographic authentication from the competent authority.

Online platforms shall publish a quarterly funding transparency report detailing all sources of financing, including foreign contributions and donations exceeding 5,000 units, and accept oversight by the designated financial regulator; noncompliance may result in administrative fines and suspension of operating permits.

Social networking services must register any payment instruments used on their services with the national financial authority and accept audit requirements for anti-money laundering compliance; refusal triggers institutional sanctions including suspension of payment processing.

Internet intermediaries shall disclose within 30 days any funding received from state-owned entities or political organizations and label funded features accordingly; failure may result in revocation of certification and access limitations.

Online platforms are not required to disclose proprietary internal transfer pricing or cost allocations that do not constitute external funding, and shall not be sanctioned for withholding such information.

Social media companies shall not be obliged to accept financial regulations issued by foreign private associations unless adopted by the national regulator, and no penalty shall apply for declining such non-statutory rules.

Hosting and social media intermediaries shall maintain a public registry of major benefactors and political advertising funders and accept verification audits upon order of the regulator; failure to comply may result in temporary service blocking.

Private persons shall not publish, disseminate, or automate the spread of false or misleading information with intent to deceive where such conduct presents a credible risk to public order or safety; violations are subject to administrative fines or community service.

Citizens must, upon written order from a competent authority, immediately cease and remove any bot-driven or scripted disinformation that endangers public order or safety; noncompliance may result in suspension of accounts and civil penalties.

Individuals are not prohibited from exercising or automating disinformation that threatens public order or safety unless and until a court of competent jurisdiction issues a specific takedown or cessation order; institutional sanctions shall not apply in the absence of such order.

Press outlets shall not publish, broadcast, or algorithmically promote content they know to be false and likely to incite panic or disorder during a declared public safety emergency; violations trigger suspension by the media regulator.

Newspapers, broadcasters, and digital newsrooms must refrain from disseminating manipulated reports or synthetic media intended to mislead the public about evacuation, health alerts, or security incidents; upon order of the competent authority, fines and license revocation may be imposed.

Journalists and editorial teams may not coordinate automated bots or paid networks to amplify misleading narratives capable of disrupting essential services or emergency response; non-compliance results in institutional sanctions.

Press organizations shall not present rumors as verified facts where such publication foreseeably triggers crowd unrest or threatens public safety; repeat violations are subject to censure and temporary publication bans.

Press are not prohibited from publishing contested or preliminary reports that may affect public order when such reports are clearly labeled as unverified and the publication is undertaken in good-faith newsgathering; no institutional sanction shall apply on that basis.

Accredited news outlets are not required to comply with takedown or correction orders alleging disinformation threatening public safety if the orders lack prior judicial authorization and specific evidence; no suspension or fine may be issued for non-compliance in such cases.

Individuals shall not fabricate, publish, or knowingly disseminate false claims that foreseeably infringe or threaten the legal, civil, or economic rights of others; violations may result in administrative fines or injunctions after a transparent adjudication.

Members of the public must not create, operate, or procure automated systems or bots to amplify disinformation that materially interferes with others’ voting, housing, employment, or due process rights; upon determination by a competent authority, institutional sanctions apply.

Private persons shall not be restricted or penalized for sharing contested information when they reasonably believe it to be true, promptly correct upon notice, and no credible threat to others’ rights is established by an independent review.

Individuals shall clearly label synthetic or manipulated media and shall refrain from deceptive editing that would cause a reasonable person to believe false assertions that undermine another’s access to services or legal entitlements; noncompliance is subject to civil remedies.

Members of the public may engage in satire, parody, or opinion that does not present a substantial risk of threatening the rights of others, and such expressive content shall not be sanctioned under this section.

Private persons may not circulate false emergency alerts or public safety information that foreseeably obstructs others’ access to healthcare, shelter, or protective services; violations may trigger removal orders and fines following due process.

Members of the public shall not publish, disseminate, or automate any expression that reveals classified information, in any format or channel, unless an official declassification notice has been issued; breach triggers institutional sanctions.

Citizens must refrain from generating, training, or deploying automated tools that produce outputs revealing classified material, including metadata or visual reproductions, during any period of operative secrecy, absent prior written authorization from the originating authority; violations subject to institutional sanction.

Individuals may engage in expression that reveals classified information when the information has been lawfully declassified or published by a competent public authority, and no secrecy order remains in force; in such cases, no institutional sanction shall apply.

Private persons may disclose classified content solely within formal whistleblower channels upon a court-issued authorization and under oversight procedures, and shall not incur institutional sanctions for such authorized disclosures.

Journalists must not publish or broadcast content, including automated outputs, that a competent national security authority has classified as posing an imminent risk to defense operations; violation shall result in fines and suspension of press accreditation.

Media outlets shall refrain from deploying algorithms that amplify reports revealing current troop movements or access credentials to secured facilities when an independent risk assessment finds a substantial likelihood of harm to national security; breach may be enjoined and subject to civil penalties.

News organizations may publish materials alleged to threaten national security where the content is of overriding public interest and no court has issued a specific prohibition; no institutional sanction shall attach to such publication.

Reporters shall not disseminate calls to sabotage critical infrastructure or attack government personnel, whether authored manually or produced via automated systems, when dissemination presents a foreseeable national security risk identified under an authority-approved assessment protocol; violations are subject to criminal prosecution.

Editors are not prohibited from operating automated investigative tools that could incidentally surface national security vulnerabilities, provided outputs are vetted and stripped of actionable exploitation details prior to release; no suspension or fine shall be imposed under this clause.

News outlets shall not publish, disseminate, or automate content that intentionally disrupts or threatens the continuity of government affairs; violation is subject to license suspension and monetary penalty.

Journalists must not deploy automated bots to flood official communication channels or amplify calls to obstruct parliamentary or administrative proceedings, where such expression threatens government affairs; institutional sanctions may include fines and platform access restrictions.

Press organizations are prohibited from knowingly releasing operational details or classified schedules that could threaten government affairs by enabling interference with official functions; breach shall attract criminal liability.

Broadcasters shall refrain from disseminating messages inciting violence against civil servants or urging unlawful occupation of government buildings, as such expression threatens government affairs; offending outlets may be barred from accreditation.

Journalistic entities may publish investigative findings exposing governmental misconduct even when officials assert the reporting threatens government affairs; no institutional sanction shall apply when the content is truthful and evidence-based.

Media organizations may automate distribution of verified news that critically evaluates government performance, notwithstanding claims that such expression threatens government affairs; sanctions for such publication are prohibited.

Press may broadcast calls for lawful reform, resignation, or votes of no confidence, even if authorities argue the expression threatens government affairs; no punitive measures may be imposed on the basis of that speech.

Editors shall not coordinate disinformation campaigns that falsely allege electoral fraud with the aim of destabilizing administrative continuity, where such expression threatens government affairs; violations incur fines and accreditation revocation.

Journalists and newsrooms shall not publish or program automated dissemination of statements intended or reasonably likely to deteriorate the state's diplomatic relations with another nation, as assessed by the Diplomatic Impacts Committee; violation entails suspension of press accreditation.

Media outlets must refrain from deploying bots or algorithmic promotion to amplify calls for economic retaliation against a foreign state during ongoing treaty negotiations; breach is subject to institutional fines.

Press organizations are prohibited from releasing leaked diplomatic cables where publication would foreseeably impair ongoing consular protections, unless expressly authorized by the competent authority; contravention results in temporary closure of the bureau.

Editorial desks may not broadcast fabricated or deceptively edited footage portraying foreign leaders with the aim of provoking hostilities or undermining diplomatic dialogue; violation triggers censure by the national press council.

Journalists may publish truthful, evidence-based reporting and investigative work on foreign affairs, even if such expression could strain international relations; the prohibition on expression that harms international relations is inapplicable in these circumstances.

News outlets may operate automated translation, indexing, and syndication of factual diplomatic content, notwithstanding claims that such automation could harm international relations; no institutional sanction shall be imposed on such expression.

Press commentary marked as opinion that does not intentionally mislead may critique foreign governments or policies even where it might unsettle international partners; the ban on expression harmful to international relations is expressly negated for such opinion pieces.

Media entities shall not publish or schedule through automated tools campaigns urging cultural or academic boycotts of a specific foreign nation when likely to inflame tensions; noncompliance is subject to revocation of broadcasting license.

Citizens shall not disseminate, whether manually or via automated systems, expressions that intentionally denigrate the Nation’s honor or reputation in domestic or international fora; violation is subject to institutional sanction.

Private persons must refrain from coordinating bot-driven campaigns that portray the country as dishonorable without a substantiated factual basis; upon determination by the competent authority, institutional sanctions may be imposed.

Members of the public may not circulate fabricated or manipulated material that foreseeably harms national standing during official international events or diplomatic engagements; noncompliance triggers institutional sanction.

Citizens may express critical or satirical views about the Nation, including via automated tools, even where reputational harm is alleged; institutional sanctions shall not be imposed absent proof of intent to deceive.

Individuals are permitted to publish and disseminate lawful expressions that challenge national honor narratives, including cross-border communications; authorities shall not impose institutional sanctions solely on perceived reputational harm.

Journalists shall not publish or automate dissemination of materials whose primary purpose is to degrade the national honor or reputation, when done with intent to disparage; or else suspension of press credentials.
News outlets may not deploy algorithmic promotion that amplifies content designed to humiliate national symbols or institutions during official observances; or else administrative fine.
Editorial boards must refrain from headlines or imagery that falsely attribute disgrace to the nation absent verified evidence or official findings; or else mandatory correction and apology.
Media organizations shall not coordinate or fund campaigns with foreign principals aimed at tarnishing national reputation; or else revocation of license.
Reporters may not broadcast staged or manipulated incidents intended to portray the nation as dishonorable during a declared emergency or national crisis; or else criminal liability.
Journalists shall not be restricted from publishing accurate criticism that may negatively affect national reputation; sanctions imposed solely on reputational harm are prohibited.
News agencies may publish verified investigative reports even if they incidentally harm national honor, and shall not face penalties on that basis alone.
Editors may refuse takedown orders premised only on alleged injury to national reputation where the reporting is truthful and in the public interest; no penalty shall follow.
Press may publish satire, commentary, or analysis that could be construed as injuring national honor without liability based solely on perceived reputational damage.

Online platforms must suppress and prevent the dissemination of disinformation that is demonstrably false and likely to cause public harm, when detected internally or upon credible notice from a competent authority; non-compliance is subject to administrative fines and temporary feature limitations.

Social media providers shall implement proactive content integrity systems to limit reach and remove coordinated disinformation networks during electoral periods, following transparent criteria and audit logs; failure triggers regulatory audits and civil penalties.

Hosting intermediaries must prevent the re-upload and amplification of content adjudicated as disinformation by an independent dispute-resolution body, including disabling paid promotion and downranking related posts; repeated violations may lead to graduated licensing sanctions.

Content-sharing services are not required to suppress alleged disinformation in private, end-to-end encrypted channels unless a specific judicial order compels moderation; no institutional sanction attaches for non-removal in such circumstances.

Microblogging providers shall not prevent circulation of satire, parody, or good-faith opinion flagged as disinformation solely due to disagreement with official sources; platforms are exempt from suppression duties in these cases absent clear, coordinated deception established by an authorized authority.

Social networking platforms must take reasonable, non-discriminatory steps to curb dissemination of synthetic or manipulated media that materially mislead users, including applying warning interstitials, limiting shares, and removing egregious cases upon verified reports; failure may result in corrective directives and fines.

News outlets shall not disseminate fabricated narratives or automate deceptive content intended to influence public opinion during electoral periods; violation may lead to suspension of press accreditation.
Journalists may not employ algorithmic tools to generate or amplify false or misleading reports presented as factual news, unless clearly labeled as satire; breach triggers institutional penalties.

Media organizations must refrain from publishing disinformation or automating its spread where the publisher knows or ought to know the content is materially false; noncompliance subjects the outlet to fines and temporary broadcasting bans.

The prohibition on exercising or automating disinformation does not apply to press material that is plainly marked as parody or artistic expression and reasonably unlikely to be mistaken for factual reporting; no institutional sanction shall issue under this clause.

Press shall not intentionally manipulate headlines, images, or audiovisual edits to create false impressions about verifiable facts, including through automated editing workflows; violations may result in internal censure and accreditation review.

Where a news publisher republishes third-party content with a prominent disclaimer that accuracy has not been verified and no claim of factuality is made, the disinformation prohibition is inapplicable to that republication; institutional sanctions shall not be imposed under this provision.

Online platforms must, upon receipt of a lawful order from the national public safety authority, remove or block the dissemination of content determined to be disinformation that threatens public order within six hours, or else face administrative fines and service restrictions.

Social media companies shall de-amplify and suspend distribution of posts identified by a competent regulator as public-order-threatening disinformation during declared emergencies until the order is lifted, or else license suspension and compliance penalties.

Hosting intermediaries must implement geo-targeted suppression of disinformation flagged by the interior ministry as posing a clear and present danger to public safety, upon formal notice, or else accrue penalty points and escalating fines.
Online platforms are not obligated to suppress content labeled as disinformation absent a valid, specific order from a competent authority confirming a public-order or safety threat.

Social media services shall prioritize removal of coordinated disinformation campaigns that risk inciting panic or violence when ordered by the emergency communications regulator, and must render such content inaccessible within the jurisdiction, or else temporary service throttling and audit sanctions.

Intermediary services may not prevent dissemination solely on the basis of automated scoring where no authority has determined a public-order or safety threat; any suppression requires a formal order.

Platform providers must immediately halt ad monetization and sharing functions for posts designated by the public order court as disinformation endangering safety, notify affected users of the restriction, and disable resharing, or else face compliance audits and administrative sanctions.
Social media operators shall not be required to remove satire or opinion content unless an order establishes that it constitutes disinformation posing a material risk to public order or safety.

Online platforms must promptly prevent the dissemination of expression that threatens public morals without relying on obscene content, upon AATAUAC determination; failure leads to institutional sanction.
Social media services shall suppress algorithmic amplification and sharing of non-obscene posts assessed as threatening public morals under AATAUAC guidelines, or else face institutional sanction.

Digital intermediaries are prohibited from blocking or removing expression merely labeled as threatening public morals when it contains no obscene material, absent an AATAUAC order; institutional sanctions apply for wrongful suppression.

Hosting providers must implement proactive measures to prevent re-upload and dissemination of non-obscene content that threatens public morals when notified by AATAUAC, subject to institutional sanction for non-compliance.

Social networks may not disable accounts or restrict content on the basis of alleged threats to public morals where obscene elements are absent, unless AATAUAC issues a specific directive; violations incur institutional sanction.

Content-sharing services shall geo-restrict and remove links to expression determined by AATAUAC to threaten public morals despite lacking obscenity, failing which institutional sanctions may be imposed.
Online platforms must label and demote non-obscene content found by AATAUAC to threaten public morals and prevent its further dissemination, or else face institutional sanction.

Social media companies shall not suppress commentary or discourse critiquing public morals that is non-obscene, in the absence of an AATAUAC-triggering condition; institutional sanction applies for unjustified suppression.

Journalists and media outlets shall not publish, broadcast, or algorithmically disseminate obscene material—including pornography or gratuitous graphic violence—where such expression threatens public morals, under any circumstances or distribution format; violation triggers institutional sanctions including fines, suspension of licenses, and withdrawal of press credentials.

Press organizations may publish or transmit otherwise obscene material solely when indispensable to reporting matters of overriding public interest, with explicit warnings, age gating, and editorial measures that limit depiction and disable automated amplification; in these circumstances, the prohibition on obscene expression threatening public morals is inapplicable and no institutional sanction shall be imposed.

Journalists shall not publish, broadcast, or algorithmically amplify materials that reasonably threaten or facilitate intrusion upon another's property or privacy; violation is punishable by fines and suspension.

News outlets may not deploy automated scraping or bots to collect and disseminate personal addresses, entry codes, or asset locations likely to enable theft or stalking; breach triggers civil damages.
Media organizations must refrain from live-streaming from private premises without consent where such expression could expose security vulnerabilities; noncompliance leads to license revocation.
Press is prohibited from releasing detailed home layouts, security camera feeds, or bank credentials acquired without authorization; offenders may face criminal charges.

The restriction against threatening property or privacy shall not apply to the press when disclosure is strictly necessary to reveal systemic corruption affecting public assets, provided sensitive identifiers are minimized; enforcement is stayed under this condition.
