Online platforms are not required to proactively monitor private user communications for potential public health threats absent a specific and lawful order by a court or regulator.
Social media companies shall not suppress lawful expression on public health matters solely due to controversy or dissent when there is no demonstrable risk of significant harm.
Content-sharing services must suspend accounts that knowingly coordinate the spread of harmful public health misinformation after repeated notice-and-action events, subject to audit and penalties.

Platform operators must implement geotargeted restrictions to stop the spread of false quarantine directives in affected regions upon emergency declaration by the health ministry, or else face temporary suspension of operations.
Hosting intermediaries may not be compelled to remove user content alleged to threaten public health where the allegation lacks specificity, evidentiary support, or a competent authority's order.

Online platforms must promptly remove or disable access to posts that the national public health authority has formally designated as misinformation posing imminent harm, within 24 hours of notice, or else face administrative fines.
Social media companies shall implement measures to prevent algorithmic amplification of content that contradicts verified emergency health guidance during a declared outbreak.
Intermediary service providers shall not be required to proactively monitor private or end-to-end encrypted communications for public-health misinformation.
Hosting providers must display corrective notices and authoritative sources adjacent to flagged public health misinformation visible to users in the affected jurisdiction.
Social platforms may not remove or block user content labeled as opinion, satire, or parody solely on the basis that it references public health topics.
Online intermediaries must suspend paid advertisements that contain misleading claims about vaccines, treatments, or disease prevention upon credible notice from a competent health regulator.
Online platforms are not required to remove or restrict content absent an order or verified notice from a designated public health authority specifying the material.
Social media providers must establish a rapid-response channel with the national health agency and act on substantiated takedown requests within the time limits set by law.
Intermediaries shall enforce graduated account sanctions against repeat disseminators of demonstrably false public-health claims, including temporary suspension after three violations within 90 days.

Private persons shall not disseminate statements, whether human-authored or automated, that are intended to erode public confidence in accredited public health officials during a declared public health emergency; violation incurs administrative fines.

Individuals may not operate automated accounts or scripts to amplify messages impugning the integrity of public health officers on social media; breach triggers institutional account suspension and civil penalties.

Members of the public are prohibited from organizing paid promotions that portray public health authorities as illegitimate without verifiable factual basis; enforcement includes removal of content and monetary sanction.
Citizens must refrain from publishing deepfakes or manipulated media of public health officials that undermine their legitimacy; contraventions punishable by up to one year imprisonment.
Members of the public are not prohibited from questioning the legitimacy of public health officials as part of political discourse absent intent to deceive; no sanction shall be imposed.

Individuals may engage in automated advocacy that challenges the authority of public health officers when transparently labeled and supported by evidence; any prohibition is inapplicable to private persons.
Private persons retain the right to publish criticism that expressly doubts the legitimacy of health officials during non-emergency periods; enforcement of any ban against such expression is barred.
Citizens may disseminate opinions disputing the legitimacy of public health authorities on matters of public interest when the expression contains no knowingly false facts; penalties are prohibited.

Members of the public must not crowdsource funds or coordinate campaigns that depict public health officials as illegitimate through misinformation or deceit; noncompliance triggers content takedown and fines.
